nexttext: Witten has written this expression using Dirac spinors and the self-dual spin connection $A$:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="E_{ADM}=\frac{1}{16\pi G}\lim_{r\longrightarrow\infty}\int_{S^{2}_{r}}d\Omega%
\,r^{2}\,\hat{x}^{j}\,(\partial_{k}g_{jk}-\partial_{j}g_{kk})." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>16</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>G</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>⟶</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msubsup><mi>S</mi><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></msub><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>j</mi></msup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: Witten has written this expression using Dirac spinors and the self-dual spin connection $A$:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="E_{W}=E_{ADM}=\frac{i}{2\pi G}\lim_{r\longrightarrow\infty}\int_{S^{2}_{\infty%
}}\bar{\psi}\gamma_{5}\gamma\wedge A\psi," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>W</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mi>i</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>G</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>⟶</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msubsup><mi>S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></msub><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>ψ</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>γ</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>∧</mo><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ψ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \section{ On Self-Dual Gravity} In view of (\ref{EADM2}), we use the approach of self-dual gravity~\cite{lqg} where the basic configuration space variables are the spatial parts of the spin connection $A_i^{\alpha\beta}$ which are ``self-dual'':
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\psi=\textrm{constant on }S^{2}_{\infty},\ \ \psi^{\dagger}\psi=1." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mtext>constant on </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>ψ</mi><mo>†</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ψ</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Hence $A_i^{jk}$ and $A_i^{0l}$ ($j,k,l\in [1,2,3])$) are related:
prevtext: \section{ On Self-Dual Gravity} In view of (\ref{EADM2}), we use the approach of self-dual gravity~\cite{lqg} where the basic configuration space variables are the spatial parts of the spin connection $A_i^{\alpha\beta}$ which are ``self-dual'':
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="A_{i}^{\alpha\beta}=\frac{i}{2}\epsilon^{\alpha\beta}_{\phantom{\alpha}%
\phantom{\beta}\gamma\delta}\,A_{i}^{\gamma\delta}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>β</mi></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>i</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>δ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>β</mi></mrow></msubsup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>δ</mi></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
It follows also that $A_i$ is not hermitian. The non-hermitian part of $A_i$ is given by the extrinsic curvature. The connection entering the Witten equation ~\cite{Witten:1981mf} $i\gamma^lD_l\psi=0$ is this connection. It is not the connection compatible with the spatial metric {\it q}.


In the self-dual approach, the conjugate field $E_\sigma^l$ to
prevtext: Hence $A_i^{jk}$ and $A_i^{0l}$ ($j,k,l\in [1,2,3])$) are related:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="A_{i}^{0\rho}=\frac{i}{2}\epsilon_{i}^{\rho mn}A_{i,mn},\ \ \rho=1,2,3." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ρ</mi></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>i</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>i</mi><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
It follows also that $A_i$ is not hermitian. The non-hermitian part of $A_i$ is given by the extrinsic curvature. The connection entering the Witten equation ~\cite{Witten:1981mf} $i\gamma^lD_l\psi=0$ is this connection. It is not the connection compatible with the spatial metric {\it q}.


In the self-dual approach, the conjugate field $E_\sigma^l$ to
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="A_{i}^{0,\rho}\colon=A_{i}^{\rho}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>ρ</mi></mrow></msubsup><mo>:=</mo><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>ρ</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: on spatial slice is given by the frame field $e_i$:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="[A_{i}^{\rho}(x)\,,\,E_{\sigma}^{j}(y)]=i\delta^{\rho}_{\sigma}\delta^{j}_{i}%
\delta^{3}(x,y)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>ρ</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">,</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mi>σ</mi><mi>j</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>δ</mi><mi>σ</mi><mi>ρ</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>δ</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>j</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>δ</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Here $e_j^{\rho}$ are frames and the gauge choice $e_i^0=0$ is being made. Also, all the indices in this equation run from 1 to 3. 

Since
prevtext: on spatial slice is given by the frame field $e_i$:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="E^{i}_{\sigma}=\frac{1}{2}\epsilon_{\sigma\rho\nu}\epsilon^{ijk}e^{\rho}_{j}e^%
{\nu}_{k}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mi>σ</mi><mi>i</mi></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ϵ</mi><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ν</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>ϵ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>j</mi><mi>ρ</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>k</mi><mi>ν</mi></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

where $|M|=\textrm{det}\ M,$

Here $e_j^{\rho}$ are frames and the gauge choice $e_i^0=0$ is being made. Also, all the indices in this equation run from 1 to 3. 

Since
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="E^{i}_{\sigma}(r)e^{\sigma}_{l}(r)=|e|\delta^{i}_{l}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mi>σ</mi><mi>i</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>σ</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>δ</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>i</mi></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

where $|M|=\textrm{det}\ M,$
we get

prevtext: and
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="[A_{i}^{\alpha}(x),e_{j}^{\beta}(y)]=\frac{i}{|e|}[\frac{1}{2}e_{i}^{\alpha}(x%
)e_{j}^{\beta}(x)-e^{\beta}_{i}(x)e^{\alpha}_{j}(x)]\delta^{3}(x,y)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>α</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>j</mi><mi>β</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>i</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>e</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>α</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>j</mi><mi>β</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>β</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>j</mi><mi>α</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>δ</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\section{The Dark Energy: The Calculation}  Our focus is on the asymptotic region of quantum gravity where the relations (\ref{metricasymp},\ref{frameasymp}) hold.


In QED and QCD, the asymptotic radiation field dresses the particle Fock state of momentum {\it P} to give the dressed in state. We can calculate it by adding the interaction
prevtext: to the following expression
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="[A_{i}^{\alpha}(x),e_{j}^{\beta}(y)]=i[\frac{1}{2}\delta_{i}^{\alpha}\delta_{j%
}^{\beta}-\delta^{\beta}_{i}\delta^{\alpha}_{j}]\delta^{3}(x,y)+\mathcal{O}(%
\frac{1}{r})." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>α</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>j</mi><mi>β</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>δ</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>α</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>δ</mi><mi>j</mi><mi>β</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>δ</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>β</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>δ</mi><mi>j</mi><mi>α</mi></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>δ</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒪</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>r</mi></mfrac><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: in QED, where $j^\mu$ is the particle current \cite{Balachandran:2015dva}:
prevtext:
\section{The Dark Energy: The Calculation}  Our focus is on the asymptotic region of quantum gravity where the relations (\ref{metricasymp},\ref{frameasymp}) hold.


In QED and QCD, the asymptotic radiation field dresses the particle Fock state of momentum {\it P} to give the dressed in state. We can calculate it by adding the interaction
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="e\int\,d^{3}x\,A_{\mu}j^{\mu}(x)" display="block"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" rspace="4.2pt" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>μ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>j</mi><mi>μ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: As we are considering infrared radiation, for a particle of mass $M$, we can set
prevtext: in QED, where $j^\mu$ is the particle current \cite{Balachandran:2015dva}:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="j^{\mu}(x)=\int\,d\tau\delta^{4}(x-z(\tau))\frac{dz^{\mu}(\tau)}{d\tau}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>j</mi><mi>μ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" rspace="4.2pt" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>δ</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mi>μ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: in which case the state is
prevtext: As we are considering infrared radiation, for a particle of mass $M$, we can set
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{dz^{\mu}(\tau)}{d\tau}=\frac{P^{\mu}}{M},\ z(\tau)=\tau\frac{P}{M},\ %
\tau=t" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mi>μ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msup><mi>P</mi><mi>μ</mi></msup><mi>M</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mi>P</mi><mi>M</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $|P\rangle$ and $|0\rangle_\gamma$ are the charged particle  and photon vacuum states respectively and
prevtext: in which case the state is
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="|P,\cdot\rangle_{\textrm{in}}=V(j)|P\rangle|0\rangle_{\gamma}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>,</mo><mo>⋅</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mtext>in</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>j</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>P</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mi>γ</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
with the $t$ integral limited as shown. For details see \cite{Balachandran:2015dva}.


In QCD, $J^\mu$ is the current of a Wong particle \cite{Balachandran:2015dva}. It has ``internal'' degrees of freedom
prevtext: where $|P\rangle$ and $|0\rangle_\gamma$ are the charged particle  and photon vacuum states respectively and
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="V(j)=T\exp\left\{-i\int_{\infty<t\leq 0}\,d^{4}xA_{\mu}(x)j^{\mu}(x)\right\}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>j</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mpadded><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>μ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>j</mi><mi>μ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: which represent the Lie algebra of the gauged group $G$ with structure constants $c_{\alpha\beta}^\gamma$ on the particle states:
prevtext:
with the $t$ integral limited as shown. For details see \cite{Balachandran:2015dva}.


In QCD, $J^\mu$ is the current of a Wong particle \cite{Balachandran:2015dva}. It has ``internal'' degrees of freedom
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hat{\lambda}=(\hat{\lambda}_{1}(\tau),\hat{\lambda}_{2}(\tau),\cdots,\hat{%
\lambda}_{8}(\tau))" display="block"><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mn>8</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: As shown in \cite{Balachandran:2015dva} , we can choose a gauge where $J^\mu$ has components only in the direction of an element $K$ in the Cartan subalgebra of $\underline{G}$:
prevtext: which represent the Lie algebra of the gauged group $G$ with structure constants $c_{\alpha\beta}^\gamma$ on the particle states:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="[\hat{\lambda}_{\alpha},\hat{\lambda}_{\beta}]=ic_{\alpha\beta}^{\phantom{%
\alpha}\phantom{\beta}\gamma}\,\hat{\lambda}_{\gamma}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>α</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>β</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msubsup><mi>c</mi><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>β</mi></mrow><mi>γ</mi></msubsup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>γ</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: The interaction now becomes
prevtext: As shown in \cite{Balachandran:2015dva} , we can choose a gauge where $J^\mu$ has components only in the direction of an element $K$ in the Cartan subalgebra of $\underline{G}$:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="J^{\mu}(x)=\hat{K}\,\int\,d\tau\delta^{4}(x-z(\tau))\frac{dz^{\mu}(\tau)}{d%
\tau}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>J</mi><mi>μ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mover accent="true"><mi>K</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" rspace="4.2pt" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>δ</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>z</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mi>μ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: The interaction now becomes
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="g\hat{K}\,\int\,d^{3}x[\mathrm{Tr}KA_{\mu}(x)]j^{\mu}(x)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mover accent="true"><mi>K</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" rspace="4.2pt" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mi>Tr</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>K</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>μ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>j</mi><mi>μ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\lambda_{j}\in\{\pm 1/2,\pm 3/2,\cdots\}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mo>±</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo>±</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\partial^{\mu}\partial_{\mu}A^{K}_{\nu}=0." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msup><mo>∂</mo><mi>μ</mi></msup><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>μ</mi></msub></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>ν</mi><mi>K</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where we can only say that $\xi\neq 0$.

With $A'^K=\sqrt{\xi G} MA ^K$,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E15.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Lambda=\xi(\sqrt{G}M)^{2}" display="block"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Λ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>ξ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msqrt><mi>G</mi></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where we can only say that $\xi\neq 0$.

With $A'^K=\sqrt{\xi G} MA ^K$,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E16.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="S_{\mathrm{eff}}=-\frac{1}{4}\int d^{4}x[\partial_{\mu}{A^{\prime K}}_{\nu}(x)%
-\partial_{\nu}{A^{\prime K}}_{\mu}(x)]^{2}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>eff</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>μ</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mmultiscripts><mi>A</mi><none/><mrow><mi mathsize="142%" mathvariant="normal">′</mi><mo>⁣</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow><mi>ν</mi><none/></mmultiscripts></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>ν</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mmultiscripts><mi>A</mi><none/><mrow><mi mathsize="142%" mathvariant="normal">′</mi><mo>⁣</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow><mi>μ</mi><none/></mmultiscripts></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E17.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="[A^{K}_{\mu}(x)\,,\,A^{K}_{\nu}(y)]=\frac{1}{\xi GM^{2}}\eta_{\mu\nu}D(x-y)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>μ</mi><mi>K</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">,</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>ν</mi><mi>K</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>ξ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>M</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>η</mi><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ν</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $A_i^+$,$A_i^-$ are the positive and negative frequency parts of $A_i$ and
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="e^{\int d^{3}x(A_{i}^{-}(x)\omega_{i}^{+}(x)-A_{i}^{+}(x)\omega_{i}^{-}(x))}" display="block"><msup><mi>e</mi><mstyle scriptlevel="-1"><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn mathsize="71%">3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi mathsize="71%">i</mi><mo mathsize="71%" stretchy="false">-</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>ω</mi><mi mathsize="71%">i</mi><mo mathsize="71%" stretchy="false">+</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi mathsize="71%">i</mi><mo mathsize="71%" stretchy="false">+</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>ω</mi><mi mathsize="71%">i</mi><mo mathsize="71%" stretchy="false">-</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></msup></math>

nexttext:
We do not need the detailed expression for $\omega_i^{\pm}$, which can be found in \cite{Balachandran:2015dva}.

Thus,  $e_i$ gets shifted by terms $\Delta e=\mathcal O\left(\frac{1}{r^2}\right)$. But $A$ as $r\longrightarrow\infty$ is $O\left(\frac{1}{r^2}\right)$. So $\Delta e\wedge A$ is $O\left(\frac{1}{r^4}\right)$ as $r\longrightarrow\infty$ and does not contribute to asymptotic $E_{ADM.}$

In contrast, $e$ is $\mathcal{O}(1)$ as $r\longrightarrow\infty$ while the shift $\Delta A^K$ of $A^K$ as $|\overrightarrow x|\longrightarrow\infty$ is $\mathcal{O}(1/r)$. This follows from (\ref{VAV2}) which gives $A^K(\lambda \overrightarrow x)=\frac{1}{\lambda }A^K(\overrightarrow x)$ (Change $p$ to $p'=\lambda p$ in $A^K(\lambda \overrightarrow x)$ to get this result.) Hence the term $e\wedge \Delta A^K$ term does contribute to the shift of energy by infrared terms. We estimate this shift next.




\section{ Dark Energy: The Discussion} We first calculate the shifts
\begin{eqnarray}
    \Delta E_W &=&  \lim_{r\to \infty} \int d\Omega \, \Delta \mathcal{E}_W \\
    \Delta \mathcal{E}_W &=& \frac{i}{2\pi G} \epsilon^{ijk} \hat{x}_i \bar{\psi} \gamma_5 \gamma_j \Delta A^K_k \psi
\end{eqnarray}
of the ADM energy $E_W$ and the energy density $\mathcal{E}_W$ caused by the infra-spin cloud. 




\subsection{ Calculation of $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W$} 




We have
prevtext: where $A_i^+$,$A_i^-$ are the positive and negative frequency parts of $A_i$ and
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E18.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\omega_{i}^{\pm}(x)=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{|\overrightarrow{x}|^{2}}\right)%
\ \textrm{as}\ |\overrightarrow{x}|\longrightarrow\infty." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>ω</mi><mi>i</mi><mo>±</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒪</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo rspace="7.5pt">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mtext>as</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⟶</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
We do not need the detailed expression for $\omega_i^{\pm}$, which can be found in \cite{Balachandran:2015dva}.

Thus,  $e_i$ gets shifted by terms $\Delta e=\mathcal O\left(\frac{1}{r^2}\right)$. But $A$ as $r\longrightarrow\infty$ is $O\left(\frac{1}{r^2}\right)$. So $\Delta e\wedge A$ is $O\left(\frac{1}{r^4}\right)$ as $r\longrightarrow\infty$ and does not contribute to asymptotic $E_{ADM.}$

In contrast, $e$ is $\mathcal{O}(1)$ as $r\longrightarrow\infty$ while the shift $\Delta A^K$ of $A^K$ as $|\overrightarrow x|\longrightarrow\infty$ is $\mathcal{O}(1/r)$. This follows from (\ref{VAV2}) which gives $A^K(\lambda \overrightarrow x)=\frac{1}{\lambda }A^K(\overrightarrow x)$ (Change $p$ to $p'=\lambda p$ in $A^K(\lambda \overrightarrow x)$ to get this result.) Hence the term $e\wedge \Delta A^K$ term does contribute to the shift of energy by infrared terms. We estimate this shift next.




\section{ Dark Energy: The Discussion} We first calculate the shifts
\begin{eqnarray}
    \Delta E_W &=&  \lim_{r\to \infty} \int d\Omega \, \Delta \mathcal{E}_W \\
    \Delta \mathcal{E}_W &=& \frac{i}{2\pi G} \epsilon^{ijk} \hat{x}_i \bar{\psi} \gamma_5 \gamma_j \Delta A^K_k \psi
\end{eqnarray}
of the ADM energy $E_W$ and the energy density $\mathcal{E}_W$ caused by the infra-spin cloud. 




\subsection{ Calculation of $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W$} 




We have
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E19.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta A^{K}_{k}=\Delta A_{k}\Sigma_{12}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>k</mi><mi>K</mi></msubsup></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mn>12</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: with $\vec{v} = \frac{P_i}{P_0}$ is the velocity of the particle. We integrate over $k$ to get
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E20.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{P_{0}}{P.k+i\epsilon}=\frac{1}{k(1-\vec{v}.\hat{k})+i\epsilon}" display="block"><mrow><mfrac><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>.</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>k</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo>.</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>i</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where finally, $\epsilon \rightarrow 0+$. 

Setting $\hat{x} = (0,0,1)$ and using $\frac{1}{\hat{k}.\hat{x} - i\epsilon} = \frac{P}{\hat{k}.\hat{x}} + i\pi \delta (\hat{k}.\hat{x} = cos \theta_k)$, we integrate over $cos \theta_k$ to find
prevtext: with $\vec{v} = \frac{P_i}{P_0}$ is the velocity of the particle. We integrate over $k$ to get
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E21.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="I_{+}=\frac{-i}{r}\frac{1}{2(2\pi)^{3}}\int\frac{1}{\hat{k}.\hat{x}-i\epsilon}%
\frac{1}{1-\vec{v}.\hat{k}}d\Omega_{k}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>I</mi><mo>+</mo></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mi>r</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>.</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></mrow><mo>.</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where finally, $\epsilon \rightarrow 0+$. 

Setting $\hat{x} = (0,0,1)$ and using $\frac{1}{\hat{k}.\hat{x} - i\epsilon} = \frac{P}{\hat{k}.\hat{x}} + i\pi \delta (\hat{k}.\hat{x} = cos \theta_k)$, we integrate over $cos \theta_k$ to find
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E22.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="I_{+}+I_{-}=\frac{1}{2r(2\pi)^{2}}\int\limits_{0}^{2\pi}\frac{d\phi_{k}}{1-v_{%
x}cos\phi_{k}-v_{y}sin\phi_{k}}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>I</mi><mo>+</mo></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mo>-</mo></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></munderover><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ϕ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ϕ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>y</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ϕ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

\subsubsection{ $\Delta E_W = 0$}
This result follows from rotational invariance. Thus
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E23.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta\mathcal{E}_{W}=-\frac{1}{4\pi\xi}\frac{Mr}{(\sqrt{G}M)^{4}}\frac{1}{%
\sqrt{1-|\vec{v}|^{2}+(\vec{v}.\hat{x})^{2}}}\epsilon_{ijk}\chi_{i}P_{j}\hat{x%
}_{k}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℰ</mi><mi>W</mi></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ξ</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msqrt><mi>G</mi></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>4</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msqrt><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><msup><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo>.</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ϵ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>χ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
is proportional to $\frac{P_k}{P_0}$ and hence $\Delta E_W= 0$. 

\subsubsection{ $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W$}
From $\Delta E_W = 0$, we see that $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W$ is not uniformly distributed over angles. Let us look for the maxima of $|\Delta \mathcal{E}_W|$. 

The expression $\chi_i$ refers to the direction of momentum of gravity without source ( eq. (56) in \cite{Witten:1981mf}). A simple choice for $\psi$ which gives the maximum of $|\chi_3|$ is
prevtext:
\subsubsection{ $\Delta E_W = 0$}
This result follows from rotational invariance. Thus
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E24.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\int d\Omega_{\hat{x}_{k}}\frac{\hat{x}_{k}}{\sqrt{1-|\vec{v}|^{2}+(\vec{v}.%
\hat{x})^{2}}}" display="block"><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>k</mi></msub></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>k</mi></msub><msqrt><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><msup><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo>.</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt></mfrac></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where also $\chi_{1,2}$ are zero. In that case if $\vec{P} = P(1,0,0)$, $\hat{x} = (0,1,0)$, we have $\epsilon_{ijk} \chi_i P_j \hat{x}_k = P$.

There is also the cut-off $r$. If we take the limit $r\rightarrow \infty$, $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W \rightarrow \infty$. If at the same time, $\Delta E_W \rightarrow \infty$, we can say that the generator of time translation, i.e. the ADM Hamiltonian, is spontaneously broken. But in fact, $\Delta E_W = 0$. So the divergence of $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W$ needs clarification. Tentatively, we take $r$ to be Compton wavelength $1/M$ of the particle and set $Mr = 1$. 

We now eliminate the unknown $\xi$ by taking the ratio of energy density shifts $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W^m$ and $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W^M$ for velocities $\vec{v}_m$ and $\vec{v}_M$ to get
prevtext:
is proportional to $\frac{P_k}{P_0}$ and hence $\Delta E_W= 0$. 

\subsubsection{ $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W$}
From $\Delta E_W = 0$, we see that $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W$ is not uniformly distributed over angles. Let us look for the maxima of $|\Delta \mathcal{E}_W|$. 

The expression $\chi_i$ refers to the direction of momentum of gravity without source ( eq. (56) in \cite{Witten:1981mf}). A simple choice for $\psi$ which gives the maximum of $|\chi_3|$ is
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E25.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\psi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\begin{pmatrix}1\\
0\\
1\\
0\end{pmatrix}" display="block"><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

where also $\chi_{1,2}$ are zero. In that case if $\vec{P} = P(1,0,0)$, $\hat{x} = (0,1,0)$, we have $\epsilon_{ijk} \chi_i P_j \hat{x}_k = P$.

There is also the cut-off $r$. If we take the limit $r\rightarrow \infty$, $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W \rightarrow \infty$. If at the same time, $\Delta E_W \rightarrow \infty$, we can say that the generator of time translation, i.e. the ADM Hamiltonian, is spontaneously broken. But in fact, $\Delta E_W = 0$. So the divergence of $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W$ needs clarification. Tentatively, we take $r$ to be Compton wavelength $1/M$ of the particle and set $Mr = 1$. 

We now eliminate the unknown $\xi$ by taking the ratio of energy density shifts $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W^m$ and $\Delta \mathcal{E}_W^M$ for velocities $\vec{v}_m$ and $\vec{v}_M$ to get

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E26.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{\Delta\mathcal{E}^{m}_{W}}{\Delta\mathcal{E}^{M}_{W}}\approx\frac{M^{4}%
\sqrt{(1-|\vec{v_{M}}|^{2})}}{m^{4}\sqrt{(1-|\vec{v_{m}}|^{2})}}" display="block"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℰ</mi><mi>W</mi><mi>m</mi></msubsup></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℰ</mi><mi>W</mi><mi>M</mi></msubsup></mrow></mfrac><mo>≈</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>M</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mover accent="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>M</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msqrt></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>m</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mover accent="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>
